DEFINITIO
1. INSTITUTIONAL SYSTEM. A complex of two or more institu col
tions of higher education, each separately organized or indepen- in
dently complete, under the control or supervision of a single admin- CO]
istrative body. . sh
ma
2, MULTI-CAMPUS INSTITUTION. An orgsnization bearing a
resemblance to an institutional system, but unequivocally designate. S.
ed as a aingle institution with either of two organizational struc- sig
tures: (1) an inatitution having two or more campuses responsible pre
to a central administration (Which central administration may or may ye
not be located on one of the adminiatratively equal campuaes) or tot
| (2) an institution having a main campys with one or more branch de
campuses attached to it.
6.
3. MAIN CAMPUS. In thoae iriatitutiona comprised of a main cam- an
pus and one or more branch campusea, the main campus (aometimes fou
called tho parent inatitution) ia usually the location of the core, ag
primary, or most comprehensive program. Unless the inatitution- Bu
i "wide or centre! adminiatrative office for such institutions ia report. log
ed to be at a different location, the main campus ia also the loca- J we
tion of the central administrative office. fin
‘ 4. BRANCH CAMPUS. A campus of an inatitution of higher educa- 7.
tion which ia organized on a relatively permanent basia (i.e. has no.
a relatively permanent adminiatration), which offers an organized un,
| program or programs of work of at least 2 yeara (as oppoaed fo qu.

FIRST PROFESSIONAL DEGREE (Item 24(6)). A degree which
mifies the completion of the academic requirements for selected
fessions based on programs which require at least two academic
ara of previous college work for entrance and which require a
al of at least six years of college work for completion. Include
ntistry, Isw, medicine, theology, veterinary medicine, etc.

PROFESSIONAL PROGRAM (Item 25(7)). A professional program, ]
the term is used here, is a program which requires AT LEAST a
r or five-year bachelor’a degree and prepares for the practice of
rofession. The term includes bachelor’s degree programs in
siness Administration, Engineering, Fine Arts, Medical Techno-
ry, Nursing, Occupational or Physical Therapy, Phamacy, etc. as
11 aa those programs leading to the first-professional degree de- :
ed above. ’

FULL-TIME STUDENTS are those carrying at least 75% of a
rmal load. NORMAL LOAD: The number of credit hours (or other
ite required for graduation) divided by the number of semestera,
arters, etc., normally required for graduation.
